2.subquestion: Express $f(\sqrt{45})$ in simplest radical form. Then evaluate its integer component under the rules defined for $f$.

subanswer.text: To express \[\sqrt{45} \]in simplest radical form, factorize \(45\) which equals \(\sqrt{9} \times \sqrt{5}\) thus giving us $$\sqrt{45} = \sqrt{9 \times 5} = \sqrt{9} \times \sqrt{5} = 3\sqrt{5}$$By evaluating integers components via definitions provided earlier:\[\lceil  3\sqrt{5} \rceil = 6,\]\because the numerator (\(\underbrace{3}_{\small{"Integer"}}))is greater than denominator('five'). Hence following formula below;\[ \lceil x \rceil := \min \{ k \in Z |k > x\}\; -\;\\    \min \{k \in Q|q>x\}, \;-\;\\    \qquad\;\,+\,[x].\quad \blacksquare\]Hereafter applying similar methodology onto other term too!\[\lfloor 3\sqrt{5}\rfloor = 5\]Combinationally their sum becomes:-$$f\bigg(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg)+f(\sqrt{45})+f(8^{\tfrac{2}{3}}) = \\6 +\color{#FF4F00}{\bf {5}}\quad\,\,\,+ \quad\quad\color{#C00000}{\bf {8}}=19.$$**Hence Final Answer Is* ****** $$f\Bigg(\frac{\pi}{3}\Bigg)+f\Bigg(\sqrt{45}\Bigg)+f\biggl(8^\frac{2}{3}\biggr)=19.$$
